text: Adam yet another Toyota has been
recalled officially today the
much-celebrated Prius yet Toyota keeps
saying they have this situation under
control do they have this under control
at all that that's the fundamental
problem that Toyota faces right now this
is the third recall that they've had in
the last few months first with the floor
mats then the stuck pedals and now
there's a problem it turns out with the
brakes on the Prius at every point
Toyota's saying this is it we've got it
under control we've answered all the
questions and then a new problem crops
up and in the consumers mind and in
future consumers minds this is just
raising an uncertainty around the brand
that for decades was kind of a sure
thing quality reliability now it's
interesting to me that now we're getting
an indication and we don't know for sure
that perhaps there's a problem in the
software particularly the Prius if that
turns out to be true how much of a
bigger of a problem is that than any of
the individual problems we've seen I
think would be a huge problem and the
reason that question is out there is
because not everybody is satisfied by
the answers of the pedal design so
they're wondering cars are rolling
computers right now and everything is
electronic so people are saying is there
a problem there that's harder to
recreate to me the story is moving it
reminds me a little bit of airplanes
when you get on a flight they tell you
to turn your cellphone off because we
don't know what effect it might have on
the planes electronics there's a little
bit of that question suddenly over these
cars is there's something going some
interference some you know sparks that
happen that throws it off that's a much
bigger question and would be a much
bigger problem for toyota and actually
would sort of raise questions about
other cars too because so many of them
use these systems that rely so much on
electronics now now I hearings have been
scheduled for Wednesday in Washington
canceled I believe because of snow right
just give us briefly an idea of what
those hearings were to accomplish and
what they'll be looking at when they do
begin well I certainly the focus is
going to be on Toyota and I think a lot
of people are going to be asking tough
questions
Toyota but I also think that Nitsa part
of the d.o.t that investigates safe tell
us what it is a national highway traffic
and safety administration that they're
going to be on the hot seat as well
because Ray LaHood the Transportation
Secretary has come out very forcefully
about Toyota and its handling of this do
t officials got on a plane to fly to
Japan to deal with this but people do
have questions about Mitsos handling of
the Toyota safety problems going back
not just months but also years and
whether they're up there were
opportunities there to to spot this
sooner than they could have and did so
as a question is this another you know
Securities and Exchange Commission that
could have seen the financial meltdown
coming and didn't and perhaps the
Transportation Department could have
seen some of these problems coming and
didn't yes and and the other analogy to
is the FAA when there's a plane crash
people say couldn't the FAA have spotted
this and perhaps there was a problem in
the records the maintenance records of
an aircraft we always want our safety
agencies to be looking over the shoulder
of every person who works at the actual
companies there isn't enough manpower to
do that of course but there are
instances there have been opportunities
our reporting has shown that where there
were clear problems and I think a lot of
people are saying that they could have
asked tougher questions and they didn't
at the time
